text: Herat (, Herāt) is a city in Afghanistan. As of 2012, about 436,300 people live there. It is the third-largest city in Afghanistan. It is the capital of Herat Province. It is in the west of the country, close to the border of Iran. The spoken language in the city is called Herati Persian or just Herati. ==History== Herat dates back to very old times. Avesta, the old book of Zoroastrianism mentions Herat as "Haroyu" and lists it as the sixth land of the sixteen perfect lands created by Ahura Mazda, the Zoroastrian god.[AVESTA: VENDIDAD (English): Fargard 1. Retrieved on 04 August 2009 http://www.avesta.org/vendidad/vd1sbe.htm] In Achaemenid times (ca. 550-330 BC), the surrounding district was known as "Haraiva" (in Old Persian). Ancient Greeks called it "Aria" and "Artacoana" was the capital of Aria. Alexander the Great took Artacoana in 330 BC and destroyed it. He later built another city near Artacoana and named it "Alexandria in Ariana", today's city of Herat. After him Parthians and Sassanians took over. Sassanians called the city “Harēv”.[Encyclopedia Iranica, HERAT ii. HISTORY, PRE-ISLAMIC PERIOD. Retrieved on 29 March 2009 http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/herat-ii] Arabs took Herat in 660 AD, and it became a center of the Muslim world. Herat has a long history as a centre for Sufism, the mystical branch of Islam. It became part of the area then known as Khurasan, which reached its peak of civilization in the twelfth century. In 1221 AD, it was taken by the Mongols and later destroyed by Genghis Khan and Timur, the Turkic conqueror, took it in about 1393 AD. Herat’s greatest era was during the Timurid rule, when it was a centre of science and culture. As the capital of the Timurid empire, it boasted many fine religious buildings and was famous for its sumptuous court life and musical performance and its tradition of miniature paintings. Later Persians and Afghans fought over the control of the city and Herat changed hands several times before it (under British interference) permanently became part of Afghanistan in 1857 under the Treaty of Paris.[Encyclopedia Britannica, Herat. Retrieved on 14 March 2009 http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/262581/Herat] In March 1979, an anti-Communist uprising in Herat, left 25,000 civilian deaths.Revolution unending: Afghanistan, 1979 to the present By Gilles Dorronsoro, Retrieved on 27 September 2009 https://books.google.com/books?id=FApipiENsgwC&dq;=herat+uprising+1979&pg;=PA98 Between 1978 and 1992, communist forces in Herat city fought resistance forces holding the countryside. In 1995 the area came under the control of Pashtuns of the Taliban movement.The Garland encyclopedia of world music, Volume 8 By James Porter, Timothy Rice, Chris Goertzen, Western Afghanistan, Veronica Doubleday, John Baily, Retrieved on 29 September 2009 https://books.google.com/books?id=ZOlNv8MAXIEC&dq;=inhabitants+of+herat&pg;=RA2-PA817 After the United States' invasion of Afghanistan, on November 12, 2001, it was liberated from the Taliban by the Northern Alliance. == References == Category:Cities in Afghanistan Category:Herat Province
